key_work.title: Welcome to Chechnya
key_work.creator_credit: David France, Tyler H. Walk, Alice Henty, Askold Kurov, BBC Storyville, David France & Joy A. Tomchin Film, HBO Documentary Films, Maylo Films, Ninety Thousand Words and Public Square Films
key_work.brief_description: This searing investigative work shadows a group of activists risking unimaginable peril to confront the ongoing anti-LGBTQ program raging in the repressive and closed Russian republic. Unfettered access and a remarkable approach to protecting anonymity exposes this under-reported atrocity–and an extraordinary group of people confronting evil.

start.title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson
start.creator_credit: David France, Faliro House Productions, Ninety Thousand Words, Public Square Films, Race Point Films, Terasem Media & Films, James O'Donnell and Mark Blane

video_links.name: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson | Official Trailer [HD] | Netflix

start.brief_description: Describing herself as a ‘street queen,’ Johnson was a legendary fixture in New York City’s gay ghetto and a tireless voice for LGBT pride since the days of Stonewall, who along with fellow trans icon Sylvia Rivera, founded Street Transvestites Action Revolutionaries (S.T.A.R.), a trans activist group based in the heart of NYC’s Greenwich Village. Her death in 1992 was declared a suicide by the NYPD, but friends never accepted that version of events. Structured as a whodunit, with activist Victoria Cruz cast as detective and audience surrogate, The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson celebrates the lasting political legacy of Johnson, while seeking to finally solve the mystery of her unexplained death.

end.title: Malcolm X
end.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Marvin Worth, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks and Largo Entertainment
end.brief_description: Malcolm X was one of the most controversial American political figures. Based on Alex Haley’s “The Autobiography of Malcolm X”. It is a landmark film in that it has an African-American as the hero of a Hollywood epic. Malcolm X was initially a small-time crim who converted to Islam and became a central figure in the the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. A passionate and dynamic speaker, his vehement condemnation of race relations fightened and incensed many white Americans. The film faithfully follows Malcolm X’s life: his poor childhood and violent early adulthood, his prison years, his involvement in the Nation of Islam and the Civil Rights Movement, and the lead-up to his assassination. Though a long film of the epic genre, Spike Lee’s direction is colourful and well-paced, and some of the sequences are dazzling, including the pilgrimmage to Mecca. Spike Lee was the first Western filmmaker allowed to film in the Holy City. “Malcolm X” reclaims, with passion and dignity, the life of a controversial but inspiring man. Denzel Washington plays Malcolm X and Angela Bassett plays his wife. Cast alson includes Al Freeman Jr, Albert Hall, Delroy Lindo.

links.description: Along with Dr King, the documentary I Am Not Your Negro featured author James Baldwin’s recollections of his friend and activist Malcom X. Legendary filmmaker Spike Lee also charted aspects of his life in biopic Malcolm X.

end.title: Star Wars
end.creator_credit: George Lucas, Gary Kurtz, Lucasfilm, Ltd. and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
end.brief_description: A Long time ago in a galaxy far far away, George Lucas’s space adventure captured the hearts and imaginations of film lovers of all ages from the moment these words scrolled across the screen. The Empire’s evil Death Star must be destroyed. The heroes, Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, Han Solo and a pair of droids named R2-D2 and C-3PO, as part of the Rebel Alliance, must pit their strength against the might of the Empire and the evil Jedi, Darth Vader. With the help of an old Jedi Knight, Obi-Wan Kenobi, they battle the forces of darkness and triumph. The special effects and famous “Star wars” theme music has ensured that this film takes its place in cinema history. Includes a ten minute interview between George Lucas and Leonard Maltin.

constellations_other.name: Eighties hunks
constellations_other.description: Thor’s hero costume from Thor: Love and Thunder was inspired by classic comics of the 80s. Gone are the military greys, replaced with bright golds and bold colours. Let’s take a look at the lineage of 80s action heroes to which this version of Thor belongs.

links.description: The Wilhelm scream is a famous shriek first used in Distant Dreams, and later over 400 films, including the Star Wars franchise. Ben Burtt, the sound designer, is credited with turning the stock sound into an in-joke between sound designers.

end.title: Metroid
end.brief_description: It’s you against the evil Mother Brain in the thrilling battle of Metroid! You’re inside the fortress planet Zebes. The planet of endless secret passageways where the Metroid are multiplying. Left alone the Metroid are harmless. But in the wrong hands they could destroy the galaxy. It’s up to you to prevent the Mother Brain that controls Zebes from using the Metroid for evil purposes. But that won’t be easy. You’ll have to use your spacesuit to absorb valuable energy for your search to gain the use of power items like the Ice Beam, Wave Beam, High Jump Boots and Varia. If you survive, it will be you and your acquired powers against the Mother Brain.

constellations_other.name: Representation of women in videogames
constellations_other.description: Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but let's face it – she's just Pac-Man with a bow. This Constellation looks at the history of female representation in videogames.

links.description: The same year, Nintendo released Metroid, another open world title that featured one of the first female protagonists in videogames. It later inspire a sub-genre of open world games called “Metroidvania”, which combined its non-linear format with Castlevania.

start.title: Princess Mononoke
start.creator_credit: Toshio Suzuki, Nippon Television Network Corporation and Neil Gaiman
start.brief_description: Ashitaka, a prince of the disappearing Emishi people, is cursed by a demonized boar god and must journey to the west to find a cure. Along the way, he encounters San, a young human woman fighting to protect the forest, and Lady Eboshi, who is trying to destroy it. Ashitaka must find a way to bring balance to this conflict.

links.description: In Princess Mononoke, demonic boars terrorise human interlopers. Fans have likened the characters to aggressive, radioactive boars spotted around Fukushima, Japan since the 2011 tsunami/earthquake caused a nuclear disaster at Daichi power plant, drawing a parallel between the film’s message and real-world concerns.

end.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
end.creator_credit: Suzanne Plunkett
end.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_primary.name: Representing disasters
constellations_primary.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

links.description: Seven years before the devastating 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami, another earthquake with a magnitude over 9 on the Richter scale was recorded and led to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and earthquake. News footage of the disaster was widely captured on amateur video and used by media outlets to document the disaster.

results.name: True blue, true crime
results.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

key_work.title: The Dry
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy Made Up Stories, Arenamedia, Pick Up Truck Pictures
key_work.brief_description:
The past and present intersect in Robert Connolly’s hit adaptation of Jane Harper’s best-selling novel The Dry.
Detective Aaron Falk (Eric Bana) returns to the drought-stricken town of Kiewarra to find out who really killed the Haddler family, while also wrestling with the mysterious death of his friend Ellie Deacon, 25 years earlier. The two crimes and timelines are entwined with the arid landscape, its harshness evocatively rendered in both sweeping, cinematic shots and intimate details, strengthening the tension of the mystery while also exposing the effects of the climate crisis on rural Australia.
Aside from its critical acclaim, The Dry became the 14th highest grossing Australian film of all time, leading a resurgence of Australian stories at the local box office.

end.title: The Boys
end.creator_credit: Rowan Woods, John Maynard, Robert Connolly, Arenafilm, Australian Film Commission, Premium Movie Partnership and SBS Independant
end.brief_description: Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, ‘The Boys’ is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods. The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house - his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) - treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film ocassionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence. The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won 4 awards at the 1998 AFI Awards - Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source”. Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

start.title: Animal Kingdom
start.creator_credit: David Michôd, Liz Watts, Film Victoria, Fulcrum Media Finance, Porchlight Films, Screen Australia and Screen NSW
start.brief_description: Following the death of his mother, J finds himself living with his estranged family, under the watchful eye of his doting grandmother, Smurf, mother to the Cody boys. J quickly comes to believe that he is a player in this world. But, as he soon discovers, this world is far larger and more menacing than he could ever imagine. start.title: The Boys
start.creator_credit: Rowan Woods, John Maynard, Robert Connolly, Arenafilm, Australian Film Commission, Premium Movie Partnership and SBS Independant
start.brief_description: Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, ‘The Boys’ is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods. The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house - his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) - treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film ocassionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence. The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won 4 awards at the 1998 AFI Awards - Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source”. Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

end.title: Paris Is Burning
end.creator_credit: Barry Swimar, Jennie Livingston and Richard Dooley
end.brief_description: Where does voguing come from, and what, exactly, is throwing shade? This landmark documentary provides a vibrant snapshot of the 1980s through the eyes of New York City’s African American and Latinx Harlem drag-ball scene. Made over seven years, PARIS IS BURNING offers an intimate portrait of rival fashion “houses,” from fierce contests for trophies to house mothers offering sustenance in a world rampant with homophobia, transphobia, racism, AIDS, and poverty. Featuring legendary voguers, drag queens, and trans women — including Willi Ninja, Pepper LaBeija, Dorian Corey, and Venus Xtravaganza.

constellations_other.name: Gender transcending larrikins

links.description: While drag is sometimes associated with only gay cisgender men, its history is much more complex and diverse. Drag performance has a distinct cultural history that is fundamentally interwoven with ballroom culture, and the trans community, as explored by the groundbreaking 1990 documentary, Paris is Burning.

constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

links.description: Barry Humphries is a straight man cross-dressing as a woman when he plays Dame Edna Everage - but Australia has a long history of queer drag, too. In 1994, drag road-trip film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, became a surprise international hit. The film’s irreverent, Aussie sense of humour paved the way for a story about queer life to enter the mainstream in a conservative time.

links.description:
Trans cabaret performer and actress, Carol Byron, was one of the biggest inspirations for The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert. She performed under the stage name ‘Carlotta’ with iconic Sydney drag cabaret showcase, Les Girls, starting in 1963. In 1973, Byron became the first trans actor to play a trans role in the world, when she took the role of showgirl Robyn Ross in Australian soapie,

Number 96.

links.description: Due to its real footage and allegedly violent themes, Night Trap was brought before the US Congress for the first hearing on videogame violence, a sign of games entering cultural consciousness. Sci-fi TV show, Crash Zone, which followed a “high tech whizz kids”, did this too, featuring game development and the internet.

start.title: The Aunty Jack Show
start.brief_description:
The Aunty Jack Show was a Logie Award–winning Australian television comedy series that ran from 1972 to 1973. Produced by and broadcast on ABC-TV, the series attained an instant cult status that persists to the present day.

The lead character, Aunty Jack was a unique comic creation — an obese, moustachioed, gravel-voiced transvestite, part trucker and part pantomime dame — who habitually solved any problem by knocking people unconscious or threatening to ‘rip their bloody arms off’. Visually, she was unmistakable, dressed in a huge, tent-like blue velvet dress, football socks, workboots, and a golden boxing glove on her right hand. She rode everywhere on a Harley-Davidson motorcycle and referred to everyone as “me little lovelies” — when she was not uttering her familiar threat: “I’ll rip yer bloody arms off!”, a phrase which immediately passed into the vernacular. The character was devised and played by the multi-talented Grahame Bond and was partly inspired by his overbearing Uncle Jack, whom he had disliked as a child, his grandfather Ben Doyle and Dot Strong the ABC’s last official tea lady.

links.description: Videogames were also grappling with technical constraints. In response to graphics limitations, some developers used footage of real actors in games. Night Trap was one, using real footage instead of 3D renderings, a technique intended to create empathy and connection between the player and the game.

constellations_other.name: Television and creative constraint
constellations_other.description: Making art for the screen is dependent on time, resources, and infrastructure. Where technology could have posed a barrier, these television producers saw an opportunity, instead.

end.title: Her Story
end.creator_credit: Sam Barlow
end.brief_description: Independently developed by Sam Barlow, Her Story uses live-action footage to follow a police interrogation and is influenced by the directing techniques of Alfred Hitchcock and the Dogme 95 school of filmmaking, as well as real-life interrogations and Sharon Stone’s performance in Basic Instinct (1992).

constellations_primary.name: Screen story searching
constellations_primary.description: Cinema, smartphones and sensuality collide in this intriguing Constellation that takes a distinctly different path.

constellations_other.name: Television and creative constraint
constellations_other.description: Making art for the screen is dependent on time, resources, and infrastructure. Where technology could have posed a barrier, these television producers saw an opportunity, instead.

links.description: Many 90s videogames and TV shows, like Crash Zone, speculated what games and the internet might look like. Now, some contemporary games look back like Sam Barlow’s Her Story, which uses footage of real actors to present players with a police procedural mystery.

start.title: [ABC TV News: First Bulletin in Colour for 1st March, 1975]
start.creator_credit: ABC and ABC-TV (Australia)
start.brief_description:
Nearly 19 years after he presented the first ever ABC TV nightly news bulletin (on 5th November, 1956) newsreader James Dibble presents the first ever ABC TV news bulletin in colour.

In this bulletin, the news includes coverage of a serious rail accident in the London underground, ongoing conflict in Cambodia, and French nuclear testing in the South Pacific. A young Jeff McMullen investigates the U.S. amnesty program for draft resisters and deserters; while Jim Revitt reports on the progress of Darwin’s recovery following Cyclone Tracy.

constellations_other.name: Television and creative constraint
constellations_other.description: Making art for the screen is dependent on time, resources, and infrastructure. Where technology could have posed a barrier, these television producers saw an opportunity, instead.

end.title: The Aunty Jack Show
end.brief_description:
The Aunty Jack Show was a Logie Award–winning Australian television comedy series that ran from 1972 to 1973. Produced by and broadcast on ABC-TV, the series attained an instant cult status that persists to the present day.

The lead character, Aunty Jack was a unique comic creation — an obese, moustachioed, gravel-voiced transvestite, part trucker and part pantomime dame — who habitually solved any problem by knocking people unconscious or threatening to ‘rip their bloody arms off’. Visually, she was unmistakable, dressed in a huge, tent-like blue velvet dress, football socks, workboots, and a golden boxing glove on her right hand. She rode everywhere on a Harley-Davidson motorcycle and referred to everyone as “me little lovelies” — when she was not uttering her familiar threat: “I’ll rip yer bloody arms off!”, a phrase which immediately passed into the vernacular. The character was devised and played by the multi-talented Grahame Bond and was partly inspired by his overbearing Uncle Jack, whom he had disliked as a child, his grandfather Ben Doyle and Dot Strong the ABC’s last official tea lady.

constellations_other.name: Television and creative constraint
constellations_other.description: Making art for the screen is dependent on time, resources, and infrastructure. Where technology could have posed a barrier, these television producers saw an opportunity, instead.

links.description: People working on screen often respond creatively to technical constraints of the time. In 1975, the first colour program aired on Australian TV: a special ep of Aunty Jack, called Aunty Jack Introduces Colour, which features the cast fighting off the intrusion of colour into black & white Wollongong.

end.title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
end.brief_description:
The next chapter in the highly anticipated Elder Scrolls saga arrives from the makers of the 2006 and 2008 Games of the Year, Bethesda Game Studios. Skyrim reimagines and revolutionizes the open-world fantasy epic, bringing to life a complete virtual world open for you to explore any way you choose.

Play any type of character you can imagine, and do whatever you want; the legendary freedom of choice, storytelling, and adventure of The Elder Scrolls is realized like never before.

Skyrim’s new game engine brings to life a complete virtual world with rolling clouds, rugged mountains, bustling cities, lush fields, and ancient dungeons.

Choose from hundreds of weapons, spells, and abilities. The new character system allows you to play any way you want and define yourself through your actions.

Battle ancient dragons like you’ve never seen. As Dragonborn, learn their secrets and harness their power for yourself.

constellations_other.name: Easter Eggs on screen
constellations_other.description: People have been slipping secrets into films, games and television for as long as they have existed.

links.description: Since Adventure easter eggs have become a way for developers to leave a mark on games they create. Skyrim contains many hidden references to media, including Minecraft, Pac-Man and Portal 2. The game contains several references to Lord of the Rings and Star Wars, too.

links.description: Easter eggs have a long history in film too. Alfred Hitchcock made cameos in 40 of his films, including The Birds, where he’s seen leaving a pet shop. These cameos became so popular, he started appearing earlier in the film so as not to distract the audience.

end.brief_description: After the devastating events of Avengers: Infinity War, the universe is in ruins due to the efforts of the Mad Titan, Thanos. With the help of remaining allies, the Avengers must assemble once more in order to undo Thanos’ actions and restore order to the universe once and for all, no matter what consequences may be in store.

constellations_other.name: Marvellous and magic MCU inventions
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, the iconic weapons Mjölnir and Stormbreaker are joined by new additions like Zeu's Thunderbolt - they're just a long line of enchanted and technologically advanced weapons in movies.

links.description: Easter eggs can also be fan service. Like Hitchcock, comic book creator Stan Lee appeared in every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe until Avengers: Endgame, where he made a posthumous, digitally de-aged appearance as a taxi driver.

end.title: Pokémon FireRed
end.brief_description:
Pokémon FireRed Version and Pokémon LeafGreen Version are a pair of core series Generation III games that are set in the Kanto region. They were released in Japan on January 29, 2004, in North America on September 9, 2004, in Australia on September 23, 2004 and in Europe on October 1, 2004.
As the first remakes in the Pokémon franchise, the games revisit the original pair of Pokémon games, Pokémon Red and Green Versions, and so feature all of the characters, plot elements, and challenges of them, but with several important upgrades to bring them up to speed with other Generation III games.
The Game Boy Advance Wireless Adapter was initially included with the games when they were first released, eliminating the need for Game Link Cables when trading between the two games (and later Pokémon Emerald Version). In later copies, it was sold separately.
FireRed and LeafGreen went on to become the second best-selling games of the Game Boy Advance, only behind Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire Versions. They also received Nintendo’s Player’s Choice awards.

constellations_other.name: Easter Eggs on screen
constellations_other.description: People have been slipping secrets into films, games and television for as long as they have existed.

links.description: While some easter eggs generate fan interest, other acknowledge theories and interests of an existing fandom. Fans believed the 151st Pokemon Mew hid under a truck in the original game. When players found the truck in remake Pokemon FireRed, players discovered a cookie that acknowledged the conspiracy.

results.name: A world of firsts
results.description: There’s a first time for everything. In their own way, these films, television and videogames each broke ground.

key_work.title: Aussie Rules Footy
key_work.brief_description: Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

end.title: The Hobbit
end.creator_credit: Melbourne House and Alfred Milgrom
end.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & paper booklet in black box
end.brief_description:
“The Hobbit” computer game for BBC Model B.
“The Hobbit” is a single-player text adventure game, originally released for the games platform ZX Spectrum 48K. It was subsequently released for other platforms including BBC. (See Documentation window for full list of game releases).
The adventure is based on J.R.R. Tolkien’s famous book of the same name.
The game cassette is accompanied by a manual with information about the game. Game cassette and manual are contained in a black cardboard box.

links.description: Aussie Rules Footy was the first AFL game and one of the first Australian games developed for the NES by Beam Software, who started out with a text-adventure adaptation of the Hobbit, which was developed by Philip Mitchell and Veronika Megler, and released in 1982.
